questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with developmental delays, including difficulties in motor coordination and speech. MRI reveals a complete absence of the corpus callosum. Which of the following is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hemispatial neglect

Explanation:

Hemispatial neglect is not typically associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum.

  • Hemispatial neglect is often seen in patients with damage to one hemisphere, particularly the right hemisphere, leading to inattention to the opposite side of space (usually the left).
  • In agenesis, both hemispheres may function independently, so hemispatial neglect is not a hallmark of this condition.


Agenesis of the corpus callosum is a rare congenital condition in which the corpus callosum, the structure connecting the two cerebral hemispheres, fails to develop properly or is absent.

  • This can lead to a range of neurological and developmental issues.

Causes:

  • Genetic: Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 13, 18) or mutations in specific genes.
  • Environmental: Prenatal factors like infections, alcohol, or drug exposure.

Clinical Features:

  • Developmental delays: Intellectual disability, motor delays, and speech impairments.
  • Seizures: Common due to lack of communication between brain hemispheres.
  • Motor problems: Coordination issues, ataxia.
  • Behavioral issues: Hyperactivity, impulsivity, and autistic-like behaviors.
  • Cognitive challenges: Attention deficits and difficulty with higher cognitive functions.

Associated Conditions:

  • Aicardi syndrome, Andermann syndrome, holoprosencephaly, fetal alcohol syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the complete syndrome triad associated with Anterior Choroidal Artery Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Contralateral hemisensory loss

Explanation:

Anterior choroidal artery syndrome is associated with the clinical triad of contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemisensory loss and contralateral homonymous hemianopia

Anterior Choroidal Artery Syndrome:

  • Cause: Infarction in the anterior choroidal artery territory.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • AChA anastomoses with posterior choroidal artery and posterior cerebral artery.
    • Infarction occurs in the posterior limb of the internal capsule due to a lack of collateral supply.
  • Complete syndrome triad:
    • Contralateral hemiplegia- Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body opposite to brain injury. (Option A)
    • Contralateral hemisensory loss- Loss of sensation on one side of the body opposite to brain injury.
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia - Loss of the same visual field (either right or left) in both eyes, opposite to the side of brain damage. (Options C and D)
      • Homonymous quadruple sectoranopia if the lateral geniculate body is involved.
      • Incongruent homonymous hemianopia if the optic tract is involved.
  • Neuropsychological associations:
    • Left neglect syndrome in right-sided lesions.
    • Language disorders in left-sided lesions.

questions.text: The labyrinthine artery arises from which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Basilar artery

 

Explanation:

  • Labyrinthine artery is a long, slender branch that typically originates from either the basilar artery or the anterior-inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It travels alongside the vestibulocochlear nerve and passes through the internal auditory meatus to supply blood to the inner ear. It is an end artery.

questions.text: In the image below, which structure is labeled as the rostrum of the corpus callosum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Structure D

Explanation:

The corpus callosum is the largest commissure of the brain. It is divided from before backwards into the following four parts:

  1. Genu: This is the thick, curved front part of the corpus callosum, located about 4 cm behind the front of the brain.
    • Its fibers curve forward into the front parts of the frontal lobes, forming a fork-like shape known as the forceps minor.
  2. Rostrum: The genu extends downward and backward as a thin extension called the rostrum, which connects to the lamina terminalis.
  3. Body: It is the central part of the corpus callosum, situated between the front (genu) and back (splenium) parts.
  4. Splenium: The splenium is the large, back part of the corpus callosum, located about 6 cm in front of the occipital region.
    • Its fibers connect the parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes of both brain hemispheres.
    • The fibers connecting the occipital lobes form another fork-like shape known as the forceps major.

 

Function: The corpus callosum is largely responsible for interhemispheric transfer of information which is essential for bilateral responses and learning processes.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient presents with rapid weight gain and persistent hunger despite adequate food intake. MRI reveals a lesion in the hypothalamus. Which of the following hypothalamic nuclei, when lesioned, is most likely to cause an uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ventromedial nucleus

Explanation:
Lesions in the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus are known to lead to uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity, as this area is critical for satiety and regulating food intake.

Hypothalamic Nuclei and Effects of Lesions

Area/Nuclei

Function

Lesion

Anterior Hypothalamic Area & Preoptic Area (Option A)

Influences parasympathetic responses (e.g., lowers blood pressure, slows heart rate, heat regulation)

Can disrupt thermoregulation and lead to hyperthermia.

Posterior & Lateral Nuclei

Mediates sympathetic responses (e.g., increases blood pressure, accelerates heart rate, cold regulation).

May cause impaired sympathetic responses and issues with stress response.

Lateral Hypothalamus (Option C)

Acts as the hunger & thirst centre; stimulates food intake.

Leads to anorexia and significant weight loss.

Medial Hypothalamus- Ventromedial nucleus

Acts as the satiety centre; inhibits eating.

Causes uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity.

Supraoptic & Paraventricular Nuclei

Secretes vasopressin and oxytocin; regulates water balance and reproductive functions.

Can disrupt water balance and lead to diabetes insipidus.

Suprachiasmatic Nucleus (Option D)

Regulates circadian rhythms and biological clocks.

Can disrupt sleep-wake cycles and lead to insomnia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the function of the Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus within the Ventral Group Nuclei?

choices.text: Influences motor activities by connecting with the premotor cortex.
Receives sensory information from the cerebellum and red nucleus.
Projects to the primary motor areas of the cerebral cortex.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Receives trigeminal and gustatory pathway

Explanation:
The Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus receives trigeminal and gustatory pathways which are responsible for processing sensory information from the face.

Ventral Group Nuclei

 

  1. Ventral Anterior Nucleus:
    • Connects to the reticular formation, substantia nigra, corpus striatum, and premotor cortex
    • Influences motor cortex activities. (Option A)
  2. Ventral Lateral Nucleus:
    • Similar connections to the ventral anterior nucleus.
    • Receives input from the cerebellum and red nucleus(Option B)
    • Projects to motor and premotor areas. (Option D)
  3. Ventral Posterior Nucleus:
    Subdivided into:
    • Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus: Receives trigeminal and gustatory pathways.
    • Ventral Posterolateral Nucleus: Receives sensory tracts; projects to primary somatic sensory areas in the postcentral gyrus (BA 1, 2, 3)

questions.text: Which of the following thalamic nuclei is concerned with recent memory and emotional tone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anterior Thalamic Nuclei

Explanation:

Anterior Thalamic Nuclei are directly connected to the limbic system and play a crucial role in emotional tone and mechanisms of recent memory.

Thalamic Nuclei:

Anterior part

Medial part

Lateral part
  • Contains anterior thalamic nuclei.
  • Receives mammillothalamic tract from mammillary nuclei.
  • Reciprocal connections with cingulate gyrus and hypothalamus.
  • Functions related to the limbic system.
  • Concerned with emotional tone and recent memory.
  • It is a part of the Papez circuit
  • Contains the large dorsomedial nucleus and smaller nuclei.
  • Two-way connections with prefrontal cortex and hypothalamic nuclei.
  • Interconnected with all other thalamic nuclei.
  • Responsible for integrating sensory (somatic, visceral, olfactory) information with emotional and subjective states. (Option C)
  • Subdivided into dorsal and ventral tiers.

Dorsal Tier:

  • Includes lateral dorsal nucleus, lateral posterior nucleus, and pulvinar.
  • Interconnections with other thalamic nuclei, parietal lobe, cingulate gyrus, occipital, and temporal lobes.

Ventral Tier:

  • Nuclei arranged in a craniocaudal sequence
  • Further divided into ventral anterior, ventral posterior and ventral lateral nuclei

Other Thalamic Nuclei

  • Intralaminar Nuclei: Influence consciousness and alertness; receive input from the reticular formation.
  • Midline Nuclei: Functions unclear; receive afferent fibres from the reticular formation.
  • Reticular Nucleus: Regulates thalamic activity; connects to other thalamic nuclei.
  • Medial Geniculate Body: Processes auditory information; projects to the auditory cortex.(Option A)
  • Lateral Geniculate Body: Processes visual input; projects to the visual cortex. (Option D)

questions.text: A 62 year old patient presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and facial droop. Neurological examination reveals upper motor neuron signs with weakness in both the arm and leg on the right side. MRI confirms an infarct in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory involving the genu of the internal capsule. Which of the following tracts passes through the genu?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Corticobulbar tract

 

Explanation:

  • The genu of the internal capsule contains the corticobulbar tract (corticonuclear tract), which is responsible for motor control of the cranial nerves, especially facial movements.
  • Damage here can result in facial weakness, as seen in the patient.

Blood Supply of the Internal Capsule:

Artery

Supplies

Tracts Affected in Lesions

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)
  • The ventral part of the anterior limb

Corticopontine tract affecting communication between cortex and cerebellum

Heubner's Artery
  • Ventral anterior limb

Corticopontine and frontopontine tracts: Impaired voluntary movements.

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • Parts of the anterior limb
  • Genu
  • Posterior limb

Corticobulbar tract (genu): Facial muscle weakness and motor deficits in cranial nerves

Corticospinal tract (posterior limb): Contralateral limb weakness or paralysis (Option B)

Internal Carotid Artery (ICA)

-

Varies depending on perforator origin, affecting similar tracts as MCA and AChA supplies

Anterior Choroidal Artery (AChA)
  • Ventral posterior limb
  • Retro-lenticular 
  • Sub-lenticular portions

Corticospinal tract (posterior limb): Contralateral motor deficits

Optic radiations (retro-lenticular part): Visual field defects

Auditory radiations (sub lenticular part): Auditory processing issues

 

Spinothalamic tract (Option C):

  • This tract is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the body to the brain.
  • It does not pass through the genu of the internal capsule.

Medial lemniscus (Option D):

  • This tract carries proprioception and vibration sense from the body to the brain, passing through the brainstem, not the genu of the internal capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following tracts passes through the genu of the internal capsule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Corticonuclear tract

Explanation:
The corticonuclear tract, which contains motor fibres to cranial nerve motor nuclei, specifically passes through the genu of the internal capsule.

Tracts Passing Through Internal Capsule:

  • Genu:
    • Corticonuclear tract (motor fibres to cranial nerve motor nuclei).
  • Posterior Limb:
    • Corticospinal tract (motor fibres to the contralateral spinal cord) (Option A).
    • Corticopontine fibres from the parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.
    • Fibres for the upper limb (anteriorly) and trunk/lower limbs (posteriorly).
    • Superior Thalamic Peduncle (through anterior and posterior limbs): From ventral posterior and lateral posterior thalamic nuclei to parietal cortex (sensory areas).

Other Tracts Passing Through the Internal Capsule:

Anterior limb

Retrolentiform part

Sublentiform part
  • Frontopontine fibres (Arnold's bundle)
  • Corticorubral fibres
  • Parietopontine,occipitopontine, and occipitotectal fibres
  • Optic radiation (Option C)
  • Temporopontine fibres
  • Auditory radiation (fibres from the medial geniculate body to the auditory cortex) (Option D)
  • Thalamic fibres to the temporal cortex and amygdala.

questions.text: Which sulcus is involved in separating the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Central Sulcus

Explanation:

  • The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe.
  • It runs roughly from the top of the brain down towards the lateral sulcus.

Lobes of the Cerebrum

  • Frontal Lobe
  • Temporal Lobe
  • Parietal Lobe
  • Occipital Lobe

Sulci of the Cerebrum

  • Lateral Sulcus: Seen laterally; separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes. (Option A)
  • Central Sulcus: Runs Antero-inferiorly; separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe; visible laterally and medially.
  • Calcarine Sulcus: Visible medially; located in the occipital lobe, associated with the visual cortex. (Option C)
  • Parieto-occipital Sulcus: Seen medially; separates the parietal and occipital lobes. (Option D)

Lateral View

Medial View

  • Central Sulcus: Divides the frontal lobe (anterior) from the parietal lobe (posterior).
  • Lateral Sulcus: Distinguishes the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • Pre-central Gyrus: Located in front of the central sulcus; it contains the frontal motor cortex, which controls skeletal muscles.
  • Post-central Gyrus: Located behind the central sulcus; houses the parietal sensory cortex for general sensations (touch, pain, temperature, proprioception).
  • Insula: Found in the floor of the lateral sulcus.
  • Central Sulcus: Separates the frontal motor cortex (pre-central gyrus) from the parietal sensory cortex.
  • Paracentral Lobule: Controls the contralateral lower limb, pelvis, and perineum.
  • Calcarine Sulcus: Associated with the occipital visual cortex.
  • Limbic Lobe: Involved in emotions and memory.
  • Cingulate Gyrus: An arch-shaped convolution above the corpus callosum.

Cerebral Cortex Layers and Functions: Has six layers of neurons.

Layer

Function

I- Molecular layer

Receives nonspecific input signals from lower brain centers.
Control the excitability of stimulated areas.

II- External granular layer

Receives nonspecific input and sends axons to the opposite cortex through the corpus callosum.

III- External pyramidal layer

Sends axons to related cortical areas on the opposite side through the corpus callosum.

The outer band of Baillarger is a part of this layer of cerebral cortex, specifically located in the motor cortex and somatosensory cortex.

IV- Internal granular layer

The primary layer for receiving input sensory signals, which then spread to the surface and deeper layers.

V- Internal pyramidal layer

Sends large axons to distant nervous system parts like basal ganglia, brain stem, and spinal cord.
Controls signal transmission.

VI- Fusiform/ polymorphic layer

Sends axons to the thalamus.

Regulates excitability of incoming sensory signals.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the anatomical relations of the internal capsule?

choices.text: The anterior limb lies between the thalamus and the posterior part of the lentiform nucleus.
The genu is located posterior to the head of the caudate nucleus.
The medial boundary consists of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.
The retro lentiform part is situated above the lentiform nucleus.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The medial boundary consists of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.

Explanation:

The internal capsule is positioned medially next to both the thalamus and the caudate nucleus

Internal Capsule

  • The internal capsule is a compact bundle of projection fibres that connects the cerebral cortex with subcortical centres such as the thalamus, brainstem, and spinal cord.
  • It contains both afferent (sensory) fibres from the thalamus to the cortex and efferent (motor) fibres from the cortex to the cerebral peduncle and midbrain.

Relations of Internal Capsule

  • Medially: Thalamus and caudate nucleus
  • Laterally: Lentiform nucleus
  • Anterior limb: Between the head of the caudate nucleus and the anterior part of the lentiform nucleus (Option A)
  • Posterior limb: Between the thalamus and the posterior part of the lentiform nucleus.
  • Genu: Bend between the anterior and posterior limbs, concave laterally (Option B)
  • Retrolentiform part: Behind the lentiform nucleus (Option D)
  • Sublentiform part: Below the lentiform nucleus.

choices.text: A-Putamen; B- Globus Pallidus; C- Caudate Nucleus; D- Subthalamic Nucleus; E- Substantia Nigra; F- Thalamus
A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Thalamus; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra
A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Globus Pallidus; C- Substantia Nigra; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Thalamus; F- Subthalamic Nucleus
A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Globus Pallidus; D- Thalamus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Thalamus; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

Explanation:

  • The basal ganglia work together to control movement by balancing excitatory and inhibitory signals.
  • They help to initiate, plan, and execute movements, as well as to suppress unwanted movements.
  • Dysfunctions in the basal ganglia can lead to various movement disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, and Tourette syndrome.

questions.text: A 70 year old female presents with tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Neurological examination reveals degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in a specific region of the brain. Which component of the basal ganglia is primarily affected in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Substantia Nigra

 

Explanation:

Substantia Nigra produces dopamine, and its degeneration is primarily associated with Parkinson's disease, leading to the classic symptoms of tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Main Components of the Basal Ganglia:

Component

Location

Role/Function

Caudate Nucleus

(Option A)

Near the thalamus and internal capsule

C-shaped structure; contributes to lateral ventricle floor; forms the striatum with the putamen; receives cortical input.

Putamen

(Option B)

Basal forebrain, close to claustrum

Part of the corpus striatum; receives input from various cortical areas and is involved in motor control.

Globus Pallidus

(Option D)

Basal ganglia; divided into internal and external segments

The primary output nucleus; is involved in movement control pathways (direct and indirect).

Subthalamic Nucleus

Diencephalon

Receives input from external globus pallidus; projects to internal globus pallidus; uses glutamate (excitatory neurotransmitter) as part of the indirect pathway. Lesions in STN lead to hemiballismus.

Substantia Nigra

Midbrain; divided into pars compacta and pars reticulata

Produces dopamine (crucial for smooth, coordinated movements); degeneration of neurons in pars compacta is implicated in Parkinson's disease.

Nucleus Accumbens

Ventral striatum

Involved in reward, motivation, and addiction; linked to the brain's reward circuitry.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with fluent but nonsensical speech and difficulty understanding spoken language. He is unaware of his language difficulties, and his reading and writing abilities are also severely impaired. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wernicke's aphasia

 

Explanation:

  • Wernicke's aphasia: Fluent speech but impaired comprehension, often with nonsensical language.
  • Reading and writing are typically affected.
  • The patient may be unaware of their deficits, which fits this case.

Aphasia:

  • Language impairment affecting communication, caused by brain damage.
  • It has different forms depending on the location and extent of the damage.

Types of Aphasia:

Type

Description

Characteristics

Global Aphasia

(Option A)

Most severe form; few recognizable words, little/no comprehension

Common after stroke; may improve if brain damage is limited

Broca's Aphasia

(Option B)

Non-fluent aphasia

Severely reduced speech output; can't speak fluently; short utterances (≤ 4 words)

Good comprehension, poor writing; speech is laborious

Wernicke's Aphasia

(Option C)

Fluent aphasia

Impaired comprehension; fluent but nonsensical speech

Speech filled with jargon; severe reading/writing issues

Anomic Aphasia

(Option D)

Difficulty finding correct nouns/verbs.

Fluent speech, speech filled with vague words; good comprehension/reading.

Conduction Aphasia

Damage to the arcuate fasciculus, a white matter tract connecting the Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas.

Difficulty repeating sentences, trouble using phonemes correctly, and impaired ability to name objects.

Language production and auditory comprehension are largely intact.

Primary Progressive Aphasia

Gradual decline in language skills due to neurodegenerative diseases.

Slow progression in speech, comprehension, reading, and writing.

Mixed Non-fluent Aphasia

Similar to severe Broca's but with limited comprehension

Sparse, effortful speech; basic reading/writing skills

Postcentral gyrus.

Superior temporal gyrus

questions.text: A 68 year old male presents with sudden onset weakness in his right arm and face, along with difficulty speaking. MRI reveals an ischemic stroke. Which artery is most likely involved in this patient’s stroke based on his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Middle cerebral artery

Explanation:

The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral surface of the brain, including areas responsible for motor control of the arm, face, and language centres (Broca's and Wernicke's areas), which align with the patient's symptoms.

 

Blood Supply to the Cerebrum:

 

Surface Type

Major Artery Supplied By

Lateral Surface

Middle cerebral artery (primary), anterior cerebral artery (superomedial border), posterior cerebral artery (occipital lobe, inferior temporal gyrus)

Medial & Inferior Surface

Anterior cerebral artery (largest area), middle cerebral artery (temporal pole, orbital surface), posterior cerebral artery (remaining areas)

Important considerations:

  • Watershed areas: Regions of the brain located at the outermost edges of the major cerebral arterial territories are known as watershed areas.
    • These areas are the most vulnerable to insufficient blood supply during cerebral hypoperfusion.
  • Macular sparing: When the posterior cerebral artery is occluded, Central vision may be spared due to collateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.

The anterior cerebral artery (Option A) primarily supplies the medial portions of the frontal lobes, affecting leg motor control, not the arm or face.

  • It might also present with urinary incontinence, mutism, apathy, or euphoria.

The posterior cerebral artery (Option C) supplies the occipital lobe and inferior temporal lobe, which are more associated with visual processing, not motor control or speech.

The vertebral artery (Option D) supplies the brainstem and cerebellum, which would cause different symptoms like coordination issues, brainstem stroke syndromes, or vertigo.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the representation of body parts in the motor and sensory homunculi?

choices.text: In the motor homunculus, finer motor control areas like arms and legs have larger cortical regions.
The sensory homunculus shows body parts with higher acuity, like fingertips, having smaller cortical areas.
Both homunculi are in the precentral gyrus and represent the same body parts.
The motor homunculus in the precentral gyrus has larger areas for fine motor parts like hands and face.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The motor homunculus in the precentral gyrus has larger areas for fine motor parts like hands and face.

Explanation:

Homunculus: The homunculus maps body parts onto the cerebral cortex, illustrating how different areas of the brain correspond to specific body regions based on motor and sensory functions.

  • Areas with more intricate sensory or motor functions occupy more space in the brain.

 

Motor Homunculus:

  • Location: Precentral gyrus, frontal lobe
  • It is a map (‘motor homunculus’) of the opposite body half, where,
    • The face is represented most laterally and inferiorly,
    • The hand is represented in the central region
    • Leg and foot are represented on the medial surface of the hemisphere

Sensory Homunculus:

  • Location: Postcentral gyrus, parietal lobe. (Option C)
  • Function: Represents sensory perception, mapping body parts based on sensitivity to touch, pain, and temperature. Body parts with higher sensory acuity, like lips and fingertips, occupy larger areas. (Option B)

Visual Representation:

  • Distorted human figures where body parts are sized according to their brain representation.
  • For instance, hands and faces are shown disproportionately large to reflect their greater cortical representation.

 

In the motor homunculus, finer motor control areas like arms and legs have larger cortical regions (Option A): Hands and faces occupy a larger area than arms and legs in the motor homunculus.
